natural solution: If $f(x)=c$ has $6$ solutions, then the horizontal line $y=c$ intersects the graph of $y=f(x)$ at $6$ points. There are two horizontal grid lines which intersect our graph $6$ times: [asy] size(150); real ticklen=3;

real tickspace=2; real ticklength=0.1cm; real axisarrowsize=0.14cm; pen axispen=black+1.3bp; real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm; real tickdown=-0.5; real tickdownlength=-0.15inch; real tickdownbase=0.3; real wholetickdown=tickdown;

void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, bool useticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) { import graph; real i; if(complexplane) {

label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE); label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW); } else { label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5)); label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2)); } ylimits(ybottom,ytop); xlimits( xleft, xright);

real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry; for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArrx.push(i); } } for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArry.push(i); } } if(usegrid) {

xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true); yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true), p=invisible);//,Arrows);

} if(useticks) { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));

} else { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); } }; rr_cartesian_axes(-6,6,-7,7);

real f(real x) {return (x-5)*(x-3)*(x-1)*(x+1)*(x+3)*(x+5)/315-3.4;} draw(graph(f,-5.5,5.5,operator ..), red); draw((-6,-3)--(6,-3),green+1); draw((-6,-4)--(6,-4),green+1); [/asy] These lines are $y=-3,$ $y=-4$.
So, the sum of all desired values of $c$ is $(-3)+(-4)=\boxed{-7}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f x = (x - 5)*(x - 3)*(x - 1)*(x + 1)*(x + 3)*(x + 5) / 315 - 3.4"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. -5.5 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 5.5 \<longrightarrow> f x \<in> (-7, 7)"
and h2 : "\<exists>c::int. card {x. -5.5 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 5.5 \<and> f x = real c} = 6"
shows  "c = -7"
a_0.informal problem: A function $f(x)$ is defined by $f(x) = \frac{(x-5)(x-3)(x-1)(x+1)(x+3)(x+5)}{315} - 3.4$. It is given that for all $x$ in the range $-5.5 \leq x \leq 5.5$, $f(x)$ lies within the interval $(-7, 7)$. There are exactly 6 integer values $c$ in this range such that there exists an $x$ in the given range for which $f(x) = c$. Find the value of $c$. The final answer is $-7$.

fixes g :: "real => real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists>x1 x2 x3 x4 x5 x6. g x1 = c \<and> g x2 = c \<and> g x3 = c \<and> g x4 = c \<and> g x5 = c \<and> g x6 = c \<and> x1 \<noteq> x2 \<and> x1 \<noteq> x3 \<and> x1 \<noteq> x4 \<and> x1 \<noteq> x5 \<and> x1 \<noteq> x6 \<and> x2 \<noteq> x3 \<and> x2 \<noteq> x4 \<and> x2 \<noteq> x5 \<and> x2 \<noteq> x6 \<and> x3 \<noteq> x4 \<and> x3 \<noteq> x5 \<and> x3 \<noteq> x6 \<and> x4 \<noteq> x5 \<and> x4 \<noteq> x6 \<and> x5 \<noteq> x6"

This Isabelle statement says that there exists six distinct values $x1, x2, x3, x4, x5, x6$ for which $f(x)$ equals to some integer $c$, and the value of $c$ is $-7$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "continuous_on {-5.5..5.5} f"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. card {x. x \<in> {-5.5..5.5} \<and> f x = c} = 6"
shows  "sum f {-5.5..5.5} = -7"
a_5.informal problem: Suppose we have a continuous function $f(x)$ on the interval $[-5.5, 5.5]$. If there are exactly 6 solutions for $f(x) = c$ for all values of $c$, find the sum of $f(x)$ on the interval $[-5.5, 5.5]$. The final answer is $-7$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "(* function definition matching the graph *)"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. card {x. f x = c} = 6 \<longrightarrow> c \<in> {-7}"
shows  "sum f {-7} = -7"
a_7.informal problem: Given a function $f(x)$ that has exactly 6 solutions for $f(x) = -7$, find the sum of all these solutions. The final answer is $-7$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "continuous_on {-5.5..5.5} f"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. card {x. f x = c} = 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> x. f x = c)"
shows  "sum f {x. f x = -7} = -7"
a_8.informal problem: Assume a continuous function $f(x)$ is defined on the interval $[-5.5, 5.5]$. If there are exactly 6 values of $x$ such that $f(x) = c$, find the sum of the function values when $f(x) = -7$. The final answer is $-7$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> -5.5 \<and> x \<le> 5.5 \<longrightarrow> f x = (x - 5) * (x - 3) * (x - 1) * (x + 1) * (x + 3) * (x + 5) / 315 - 3.4"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. card {x. -5.5 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 5.5 \<and> f x = c} = 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> c. -7 = (\<Sum> c))"
shows  "card {c. \<exists> x. -5.5 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 5.5 \<and> f x = c \<and> card {x. -5.5 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 5.5 \<and> f x = c} = 6} = 1"
a_9.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x)$ defined for $-5.5 \le x \le 5.5$ such that $f(x) = \frac{(x - 5)(x - 3)(x - 1)(x + 1)(x + 3)(x + 5)}{315} - 3.4$. Find the number of unique values $c$ for which there are exactly 6 different values of $x$ in the interval $-5.5 \le x \le 5.5$ that satisfy $f(x) = c$. The final answer is 1.
